With the Olympics still in full swing, itâ€™s the perfect time to highlight 1988â€™s â€œOne Moment in Timeâ€ by Whitney Houston!

The song was written by Albert Hammond (the man behind â€œIt Never Rains in Southern Californiaâ€) and John Bettis for the 1988 Summer Olympics in Seoul, South Korea, and released as a single from the Olympic soundtrack compilation album of the same nameâ€“produced in conjunction with NBC Sports.

The single was the studio version of the song that Whitney sang live during the opening ceremonies.

(Note: Other artists featured on the album included The Four Tops, The Bee Gees, Eric Carmen, Taylor Dayne and composer/conductor John Williams.)

â€œOne Moment in Timeâ€ was an anthem for believing in yourself against all odds, and struck a chord not only in America, but around the world.

The proof: It charted in 20 countries, all but 3 in the top 10! In the US alone, it topped Billboardâ€™s Adult Contemporary Chart, and reached #5 on the Hot 100!

â€œOne Moment in Timeâ€ by Whitney Houston gets the Gold Medal for being: an inspirational Song of Olympic proportionsâ€¦and a Great Song of 1988!

Guitarist Paul Dean of the Canadian group Loverboy went to a nearby beach on a sunny Wednesday afternoonâ€¦hoping to find something that might inspire him to write a song.

What he found was a distinct lack of people. In fact, the beach was nearly deserted.

It occurred to him that everybody must be â€œwaiting for the weekend.â€

Then it occurred to him that â€œWaiting for the Weekendâ€ was a great song title. But not so fastâ€¦

When he took it back to the group, vocalist Mike Reno thought a better title would be â€œWorking for the Weekend.â€ And soâ€¦a Great Song of 1982 was born!

At the time, Loverboy had only released one album, and they were struggling, playing to small crowds in small bars across Canada and the USâ€¦but once they added the finished song to their playlist, they started packing the dance floors. and they knew they were onto something.

In late 1981,â€Working for the Weekendâ€ became the lead single from their second album, â€œGet Lucky,â€ andâ€“as luck would have itâ€“by early â€˜1982, theyâ€™d hit the jackpot!

In Canada, the song reached #10 on the Top 40, while here in the States, it climbed to #2 on Billboardâ€™s Rock Chartâ€“while continuing to pack dance floors across North America.

Then, At the end of the decade, VH-1 listed â€œWorking for the Weekendâ€ at #100 on their list of the 100 Greatest Songs of the â€™80s!

So ironically, an empty beach inspired A Great Party Song of 1982!

1984â€™sâ€œWhat About Meâ€ is a Country Crossover that features an All-Star cast of singers and songwriters, and notable for the list of stars who DIDNâ€™T make the lineup!

Get your scorecards ready, because here we go!

â€œWhat About Meâ€ was written by Kenny Rogers, Richard Marx, and David Foster (known for his work with Chicago and scores of other artists, including his current wife, Katharine McPhee).

It was written as trio, and designed for Kenny, Lionel Ritchie, and Barbra Streisand, but then Lionel backed out, which led Barbra to back out as well.

So then it was offered to Olivia Newton-John and Jeffrey Osborneâ€¦but Olivia was working on a duet with Barry Gibb, and although she wanted to do it, the timing was wrong. Then Jeffrey had a scheduling conflict, so it was on to round 3.

The third time was the charm, as Kim Carnes and James Ingram stepped in to help Kenny completeâ€What About Meâ€ as the lead single from his albumâ€ of the same name. Whew!

The song was a about a romantic triangle, with each singer trying to work out what they felt for whom, and it immediately became a hit, topping the Adult Contemporary Charts in both the US & Canada. (How could it lose with all that star power?)

Side Note: It was the first #1 song as a songwriter for Richard Marx.)

â€œWhat About Meâ€ by Kenny Rogers, Kim Carnes, and James Ingram: an All-Star lineup with a Great Country Crossoverâ€¦on from 1984!

The â€™70s were quite the decade for John Denver: hit after hit, millions of albums and singles sold, TV specials and guest appearances, movies, extended tours, etcâ€¦etcâ€¦

The man was extremely busy for 10 straight years, so it was only natural that when the â€™80s came around, he lightened his schedule and turned his attention to several special projects and humanitarian pursuits, many involving natural resource and environmental conservation.

John still toured a bit and released a few albums and singles here and there, but his main focus was elsewhere.

That said, his last big hit was released in 1982: the simple, yet beautiful â€œShanghai Breezes.â€

John was visiting Shanghai and was starting to feel homesick, when he realized that the sun, moon, stars, and even the breezes were the same no matter where he was at the time.

That simple thought gave birth to a song that went to #1 on the Adult Contemporary Charts in both the US and Canada.

It was Johnâ€™s last #1 songâ€¦and also the last to appear in the Top 40 (at #31).

NOTE: In case youâ€™ve ever wondered, the flute solos were performed by Jim Horn, a member of the legendary group of studio musicians called â€œThe Wrecking Crew.â€ During his long career, Jim has played woodwinds for everyone from The Beatles and Beach Boysâ€¦to The Rolling Stones, The Carpenters., and Tom Pettyâ€“just to name a small handful.

â€œShanghai Breezesâ€ by John Denver: one last Great Song from a legendary performer.

If youâ€™ve been following this blog for any given length of time, youâ€™ve probably noticed that I often include Canadian chart statistics. There are 2 reasons for this:

#1: Itâ€™s no secret that many Canadian groups and artists have crossed over the border to influence American musical tastesâ€¦and vice versa.

#2: I grew up near the Canadian border, and it certainly influenced MY musical tastes! ğŸ™‚

On any given song, the chart numbers between countries could virtually be identical, or wildly different. And Then there are songs that donâ€™t cross the border at allâ€“and that can ALSO go both ways!

I bring this up because this weekâ€™s featured Great Song of the â€™80s , is a rarity: a Great Canadian Song that took 6 YEARS to cross the border and become a Great Song here in the US!

In 1983, Arnold Lanni, keyboardist for the Canadian group Sherriff, fell in love with Valeri Brown and wrote her a song for Valentineâ€™s Day. They married 2 years later, but before that happened, Sheriff recorded and released â€œWhen Iâ€™m With You.â€

The song went to #8 on Canadaâ€™s Top 40, but stalled at #61 in the US.

Now Youâ€™d think that would be the end of itâ€¦and it almost WAS, especially after Sheriff turned in their badges and broke up in 1985.

But then, in November of 1988, KDWB in Minneapolis and WKTI in Milwaukee started playing the songâ€¦and by early 1989, other stations in the Midwestâ€¦and then the rest of the countryâ€¦ had started playing it as well, which led Capitol Records to re-issue the single.

This time, â€œWhen Iâ€™m With Youâ€ went to #1 on Billboardâ€™s Hot 100 and Adult Contemporary Charts in the US â€¦but failed to chart at all in Canada!

Many people thought Sheriff should reunite and go out on tour to back the song, but the ex-band members refused, and that was that.

So in the end, Sheriff became a one-hit wonder TWICEâ€¦withâ€When Iâ€™m with You:â€ a Great Song of 1983 up Northâ€¦and 1989 here in the States.

n the mid-80s, a lack of good material mixed with a serious drug problem put Eddie Moneyâ€™s career on the skids. His record label, Columbia, was about ready to drop him, but, because he was cleaning himself up, they decided to give him one last chanceâ€“but only if he allowed them to choose his material. Eddie really had no choice but to agree.

One of the songs Columbia wanted him to record, was â€œTake Me Home Tonight.â€ Eddie didnâ€™t think it had much hit potential, but he was intrigued by the part of the song that sampled â€œBe Me Baby,â€ the 1963 classic by the Ronettesâ€“sung by Ronnie Spector (who, back in the day, was married to production geniusâ€“and future convicted murdererâ€“Phil Spector).

Eddie thought it would be a good idea to have Ronnie record the part herself, but when he was told by Columbia that she wasnâ€™t availableâ€¦he asked his friend Martha Davis of the The Motels to sing it.

Martha declined and told Eddie he should call Ronnie himself and not take â€œNoâ€ for an answer.

So Eddie called Ronnie and caught her in the middle of washing dishes. Ronnie told him sheâ€™d retired because she was tired of all the drama stardom had brought her way. Basically, she was happy to be living a quiet life out of the spotlight.

But Eddie had a comeback ready: â€œBut Ronnie, the whole song is a tribute to you!â€

That did the trick!

The song was recorded and released as a single from Eddieâ€™s â€œlast chanceâ€ album, â€œCanâ€™t Hold Back.â€ And people LOVED IT!

â€œTake Me Home Tonightâ€ topped Billboardâ€™s Mainstream Rock Chart, and reached #4 on the Hot 100! It later garnered a Grammy nomination for â€œBest male Rock Performance.â€ (Perhaps it should have been for â€œBest Duo,â€ but thatâ€™s just my personal opinion.)

Eddie Money was backâ€¦and so was Ronnie Spector, who then came out of retirement and resumed her singing career.

â€œTake me Home Tonight:â€ A double comeback for Eddie and Ronnie, and a Great Song of 1986!

Singer/Songwriter Paul Davis set out to write a song that would sound like something Hall & Oates might record, while at the same time, have sort of a nostalgic feel to it.

He called it: â€œ55 Love Affair,â€ which, in itself, is a pretty good title, but the suits at Paulâ€™s record company (Bang Records), had a question.

They asked Paul how old he was in 1955. The Answerâ€¦was 7.

At that point, they suggested he change the title to â€œ65 Love Affairâ€ since more people would believe a 17-year-old in love.

Excellent point, so Paul adjusted the title and lyrics accordingly.

And When the song was released as a single (from the album â€œCool Night,â€ Paul did indeed sound a bit like Hall & Oatesâ€¦and it was more believable, age-wise. SO believable, it spent FIVE MONTHS on Billboardâ€™s Hot 100, peaking at #6. It also reached #5 on The Adult Contemporary Chart.

The moral of the story? Sometimes when you listen to the suits, you hit the charts with a BANG! Pun intended. â€œ65 Love Affairâ€ by Paul Davis: a Great Song of 1982!

In 1983, the British reggae band UB40 was putting together â€œLabour of Love,â€an album of cover versions of songs they liked, and they decided to record a version of a rather obscure song by Jamaican-born singer Tony Tribe that only made it to #46 on the UK charts back in 1969.

Or so they thought.

Because the name of the composer listed on the sheet music was N. Diamond, they naturally assumed it was Jamaican singer Negus Diamond.

Butâ€¦in reality, it was NEIL Diamond, whose origina1967 version of â€œRed Red Wineâ€ was not even CLOSE to being a reggae songâ€“and not really a hit either.

Neilâ€™s original label was Bang Records, and when he left after releasing 2 albums, Bang started tinkering with his musicâ€™. They added a choir to the songâ€¦without Neilâ€™s knowledge or permission., and the single never made it above #62 on the Hot 100.

Cut to the â€™80s:

UB40â€™s single version was released in 1983 in the UK, and went to #1, but stalled at #34 in the US when it was released in 1984. But hold onâ€¦

In 1988, it was re-issued in the USâ€“and this time it was the full album version, including the rap break that had been edited out of the original single.

TTHIS version quickly topped Billboardâ€™s Hot 100!

Everybody was a winnerâ€“including Neil Diamondâ€“who received residuals, of courseâ€¦but also loved UB40â€™s version so much, he started performing in it concert using THEIR reggae arrangement instead of his non-reggae original!

When you put the story all together, itâ€™s pretty obvious that â€œRed Red Wineâ€ was destined to be a Great Song all alongâ€¦NO thanks to Bang Records in 1967, but with a positive nod to Tony Tribe in 1969, and the combined talents of Neil Diamond and UB40 from 1983-to 1988!

Early in his career, Richard Marx had written a song so personal, he had no intention of recording it for release.

â€œRight Here Waitingâ€ was a love letter to his wife-to-be, actress Cynthia Rhodes, who was in South Africa shooting a film. He wanted to visit her, but his visa application was rejected. So he recorded a personal copy and sent it to her by mail. (This, of course, was during the â€™80s, when there was no such thing as email or Skype.)

And That was thatâ€¦until it wasnâ€™t.

One day, Barbra Streisand asked Richard to â€œwrite her a hit.â€

After some serious internal debate, he sent her â€œRight Here Waiting.â€ The next day, she called Richard and told him she loved the music and the melodyâ€¦BUT if she were going to record it, heâ€™d have to rewrite the lyrics because, and I quote: â€œI will NOT be right here, waiting for ANYBODY!â€

Now that may SEEM like a classic example of â€œBarbra the Divaâ€ talking, but Richard has always felt that it was actually a kick in the pants to record and release the song himself.

So he didâ€¦and â€œRight Here Waitingâ€ became a monster hit!

When it was released from the album, â€œRepeat Offender,â€ it reached the Top 10 in 11 countries, including #1 in the US on both the Hot 100 and Adult Contemporary Charts.â€ It also went to #1 in Australia, New Zealand, and Ireland.

Note: Richard and Cynthia were married from 1989 to 2014.

Right Here Waitingâ€ by Richard Marx, with special thanks to Barbra Streisand: A Great Song of 1989!

Vince Gill: You may know him as a country music superstar and a member of the Grand Olâ€™ Opry. You may know him as a current touring member of The Eagles. Or you may know him as Mr. Amy Grant. ğŸ™‚

â€œLet Me Love You Tonightâ€ by Pure Prairie Leagueâ€“featuring Vince Gill and David Sanborn: a Great Song of 1980!
